title: Clouds gather over Portland as Alcoa flags closures
text:
''After the portfolio transformation, the company expects to be the lowest emitter of carbon dioxide among all global aluminum companies, per ton of emissions in both smelting and refining, and aims to move its aluminum portfolio to a first quartile cost position,'' said Alcoa in a statement.

''In addition, Alcoa anticipates that up to 85 per cent of its smelting portfolio will be powered by renewable energy, building upon the company’s existing sustainability profile.''

Rio Tinto is also working to reduce the carbon intensity of its aluminium, and is increasingly focusing on its Canadian smelters – which are powered by emissions free hydro power – rather than its struggling Australian smelters which are mostly powered by fossil fuels.

If not closed, Portland could face ownership changes, with Alcoa also flagging plans to generate up to $US1 billion ($1.48 billion) of cash by selling non-core assets.

Closure of Portland could have significant ramifications for the National Electricity Market, given the smelter consumes about 10 per cent of Victoria's electricity.

While in theory its closure could lower demand and therefore prices, experts said its closure could accelerate the closure of one of the coal-fired generators in the La Trobe Valley.

ASX-listed Alumina Limited and Alcoa collectively own 55 per cent of the smelter on Victoria's south-west coast, with China's Citic and Japan's Marubeni each owning 22.5 per cent.

Alcoa and Alumina closed another Victorian aluminium smelter at Point Henry in 2014.

The reviews announced on Thursday morning (AEDT) came after Alcoa lost $US221 million in the three months to September 30.

Mr Harvey said demand for aluminium had been weaker than expected, and absolute demand may actually contract, rather than grow by at least 1.25 per cent, as the company predicted in July.

Aluminium markets have been roiled by US president Donald Trump's trade war over the past 18 months, and the worsening picture for the metal is at odds with the upbeat assessment Rio Tinto gave in February 2018, when it said aluminium markets could be at a positive turning point.

"If China really restructures their aluminium business then that could create significant opportunities for us," said Rio chief executive Jean-Sebastien Jacques in February 2018.

"The run rate of the [Chinese] closures could be significant but we want to be really convinced those closures really happen and nobody restarts them.

"Over the medium to longer term, we expect China to be broadly balanced in aluminium, which creates significant implications for supply from the rest of the world. This could be a turning point for the aluminium industry, for which we are uniquely positioned with our 2.3 million tonne hydro-powered Canadian smelters."

Mr Harvey said he expected the global oversupply of alumina in 2019 would be bigger than previously thought.
description: Alcoa wants to cull poorly performing smelters and cut the carbon intensity of its fleet, both of which are gloomy portents for Australia's Portland smelter.
